questions.text:
Which of the following are pro-apoptotic factors?
  1. BAK
  2. BAX
  3. BCL2
  4. BCL-XL
  5. MCL1
questions.solution:
BAK and BAX are pro-apoptotic factors, whereas BCL2, BCL-XL, and MCL1 are anti-apoptotic proteins.

Apoptosis, also known as programmed cell death, occurs due to the activation and release of certain proteases known as caspases. These enzymes are regulated by a balance between the actions of pro- apoptotic and anti-apoptotic proteins on the permeability of the mitochondrial membrane:

  • Pro-apoptotic proteins increase membrane permeability, thereby causing leakage of proteins that initiate apoptosis, like cytochrome c.
  • Anti-apoptotic proteins keep the membrane impermeable, preventing the release of cytochrome c.

There are two apoptotic pathways-

  • The intrinsic or mitochondrial pathway
  • Extrinsic or death-receptor initiated pathway

The intrinsic pathway is triggered by DNA damage, accumulation of misfolded proteins, and loss of survival signals. This leads to leakage of pro-apoptotic proteins like cytochrome c into the cytoplasm. Cytochrome c binds to APAF-1 (apoptosis-activating factor-1), forming an apoptosome. This complex activates caspase 9. 

The extrinsic pathway is triggered by the engagement of death receptors on the plasma membrane. It activates caspases 8 and 10. 

The active forms of these caspases activate executioner caspases (3 and 6), which act on various cell components to cause nuclear fragmentation, DNA degradation, etc. Cytoplasmic blebs and apoptotic bodies are then formed, which are ultimately phagocytosed.

questions.solution:

questions.text:
Arrange the following cellular events of inflammation in the correct sequence:
  1. Rolling
  2. Cytokine mediated integrin activation
  3. Adhesion
  4. Migration
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of cellular events that occur during inflammation is:

  • Rolling
  • Cytokine mediated integrin activation
  • Adhesion
  • Migration

The recruitment of leukocytes to the site of inflammation is a multi-step process, that is mediated by adhesion molecules and cytokines called chemokines. This process can be divided into sequential phases:

  1. In the lumen: margination, rolling and adhesion to the endothelium occurs.
  2. Migration of the leukocytes across the endothelium and vessel wall
  3. Migration in the tissues towards a chemotactic stimulus.

The process of leukocyte recruitment is as follows:

  • Margination: Because of dilation of the inflamed postcapillary venues, there is stasis of blood flow and hence more leukocytes assume a peripheral position along the endothelial surface; this process of leukocyte redistribution is called margination.
  • Rolling: the slowed leukocytes then sense the signals from the endothelium and start rolling on the vessel wall.
  • Cytokine-mediated integrin activation: the attachment of leukocytes to the endothelial cells requires adhesion molecules that are activated by cytokines. The major families of proteins involved in adhesion and migration are selectins and integrins and their ligands.
  • Adhesions: the weak rolling interactions slow down the leukocytes and allow them to bind more firmly to the endothelium. Chemokines that were produced at the site of injury bind to the endothelial cell proteoglycans. These chemokines then bind to the rolling leukocytes and activate them. This is turn converts the ligands for β1 and β2 integrins, VLA-4 and LFA-1 present on the leukocytes to a high-affinity state.
  • This combination of cytokine-induced expression of integrin ligands on the endothelium and increased integrin affinity on the leukocytes leads to firm adhesion of leukocytes to the endothelium at the site of inflammation.
  • Leukocyte migration: this is the movement of leukocytes through intact endothelium, called transmigration or diapedesis. This occurs in postcapillary venules. This migration occurs through the inter endothelial gap towards the chemical concentration gradient created by the chemokines at the site of injury. This occurs with the help of adhesion molecules present in the intercellular junctions such as Platelet Endothelial Cell Adhesion Molecule (PECAM-1) or CD31.

questions.text: Which cytokine activates macrophages via the classical pathway?
questions.solution:
IFN-Ɣ activates macrophages via the classical pathway.

Macrophages are involved in chronic inflammatory reactions, where they secrete cytokines and growth factors that eliminate microbes and damaged tissues and activate T lymphocytes. They are also involved in tissue repair. Macrophages are activated via two pathways:

  • Classical pathway: In this pathway, macrophages are activated by cytokine IFN-Ɣ secreted by Th1 cells, microbial products (endotoxin), T cell-derived signals, or foreign substances. These macrophages play an important role in host defense and inflammatory reactions. 
  • Alternate pathway: In this pathway, macrophages are activated by cytokines like IL-4, IL-5, and IL-13 secreted by Th2 cells. These macrophages are primarily involved in tissue repair. 

T-lymphocytes and macrophages show a bidirectional interaction, where lymphocytes produce cytokines that activate macrophages and activated macrophages produce cytokines to stimulate T-lymphocyte responses.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presented with a history of seizures. Imaging revealed the presence of a tumor in the frontal lobe. Surgery was done and the biopsy image of the lesion is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of frontal lobe tumor with seizures and the histopathology image showing the ‘fried egg appearance’ of tumor cells, points to the diagnosis of oligodendroglioma.

Oligodendroglioma is a subtype of infiltrating glioma. It is comprised of cells that resemble oligodendrocytes. The tumors are composed of sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm. This gives it the ‘fried egg appearance’. The tumor cells that infiltrate the cortex usually collect around the neuron and this is known as perineural satellitosis. Also, there is a delicate network of anastomosing thin-walled capillaries between the tumor cells, resembling 'chicken wire'.

Oligodendrogliomas account for 5 to 15% of all gliomas and most commonly are detected in the fourth and fifth decades of life. Patients may have had several years of antecedent neurologic complaints, often including seizures.

The lesions are found mostly in the cerebral hemispheres, mainly in the frontal or temporal lobes.

It is treated with a combination of surgery, chemotherapy, and radiotherapy. 

Other options:

Option A: Glioblastoma is a synonym for grade IV astrocytoma. Infiltrating astrocytomas and glioblastomas are usually seen in the cerebellum, brainstem, or spinal cord. Histologically, glioblastoma appears like an anaplastic astrocytoma with serpiginous foci of palisading necrosis and microvascular proliferation. 

Option C: Ependymomas in adults are in the spinal cord and near the ventricles, particularly the fourth ventricle. The microscopic appearance shows both true rosettes and perivascular pseudorosettes. 

Option D: Schwannomas are benign tumors that often arise directly from peripheral nerves. On microscopy, they are comprised of dense areas called Antoni A  areas and loose areas referred to as Antoni B areas. Antoni A areas are eosinophilic and contain spindle cells arranged in intersecting fascicles with nuclear palisading. The central nuclear-free zones are called Verocay bodies. Schwannomas are a component of NF-2.

  • Individual tumor cells have scant cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei that are frequently elongated or crescent-shaped
  • Tumor cells form Homer - Wright rosettes (pseudorosettes) with a central neuropil

  • Perivascular pseudorosettes: perivascular nuclear - free zone consisting of thin ependymal processes radiating toward the central blood vessel

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the pathogenesis of saccular aneurysms?

choices.text: Migration of smooth muscle into the sac
Absence of intimal elastic lamina in the sac
Deposition of mucoid material in the media
Low-grade inflammation of the vessel wall

questions.solution:
The true statement about the pathogenesis of saccular aneurysms is the absence of intimal elastic interna in the sac.

Saccular (or berry) aneurysm is the most common type of intracranial aneurysm, most often occurring in the anterior circulation of the circle of Willis. Rupture of this aneurysm is the most common cause of spontaneous subarachnoid hemorrhage.

The following factors are implicated in the pathogenesis of saccular aneurysm:

  • Genetic factors: Increased incidence in first-degree relatives
  • Associated syndromes: Increased incidence in individuals with autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease, Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, neurofibromatosis type 1, Marfan syndrome, etc
  • Predisposing factors: Increased incidence in cigarette smokers and individuals with hypertension

The aneurysmal sac is made up of thickened hyalinized intima and a covering of adventitia. The absence of smooth muscle and intimal elastic lamina in the sac suggests that these aneurysms are developmental anomalies. Atheromatous plaques, calcification, thrombi, or prior hemorrhage may be present within the aneurysm.  

Rupture usually occurs at the apex of the sac. It is often associated with a sudden increase in intracranial pressure, such as when straining during defecation or sexual stimulation. Patients complain of an acute excruciating headache and loss of consciousness. The prognosis worsens with each episode.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presented with a history of diffuse thyroid swelling for the past 2 months. Investigations show increased T3 and T4 levels and the presence of thyroid peroxidase antibodies. She undergoes fine needle aspiration cytology which is shown in the image below. Which of the following findings are seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Hashitoxicosis, a transient phase of thyrotoxicosis that usually occurs in the first two months of Hashimoto thyroiditis, and Hürthle cells are seen in fine-needle aspiration in this condition.

Hashimoto thyroiditis is an autoimmune disease characterized by the gradual destruction of the thyroid gland leading to thyroid failure. It is more commonly seen in females between 45 to 65 years of age. In the majority of cases, it is caused by the presence of circulating autoantibodies against thyroglobulin and thyroid peroxidase.

Morphologically, there is a diffuse and symmetrical enlargement of the thyroid gland, with an intact capsule. Microscopic features include:

  • Extensive lymphocytic infiltrate containing small lymphocytes, plasma cells, and well-developed germinal centers
  • Hürthle cells, are epithelial cells that line atrophied thyroid follicles and contain eosinophilic granular cytoplasm

The image below shows a histopathological picture of Hashimoto's thyroiditis:

In most cases, there is a gradual development of hypothyroidism. However, in some patients, transient thyrotoxicosis may occur due to the release of thyroid hormones from disrupted thyroid follicles known as hashitoxicosis. Free T4 and T3 levels are elevated and TSH and radioactive iodine uptake are decreased in this phase. As hypothyroidism occurs, T4 and T3 levels fall, and TSH increases. Patients are also more susceptible to developing other autoimmune diseases like type 1 diabetes and systemic lupus erythematosus.  

Other options:

Options B and C: Orphan Annie Eye nuclei (nuclei with finely dispersed chromatin and a ground-glass appearance) and pseudo-inclusions (nuclear membrane grooves) are characteristic of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid, which is the most common form of thyroid cancer. Other histological hallmarks include branching papillae covered by a single to multiple layers of cuboidal epithelial cell and psammoma bodies (concentrically calcified structures within the papillae). This type of cancer has an excellent prognosis, with a 10-year survival rate in 95% of cases.

 

 

Option D. Multinucleate giant cells are found in granulomatous thyroiditis. Granulomatous thyroiditis, also known as De Quervain thyroiditis, occurs due to viral infection, most often upper respiratory tract infection. The virus destroys thyroid follicles, inciting cytotoxic T lymphocyte reaction against the thyroid antigens. Thyroid pain is the most common symptom. In some cases, there may be transient thyrotoxicosis lasting for 2-6 weeks. Normal function returns after recovery.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman presented with a large, rapidly growing painless breast lump. On examination, a smooth, multinodular breast lump was noticed. Microscopic examination of the core biopsy sample is shown below. Which of the following is an incorrect statement regarding this condition?

choices.text: Stromal cellularity is increased next to the epithelium
Absence of epithelial elements suggests malignancy
Both epithelial and stromal components can metastasize

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and image are suggestive of phyllodes tumor. Here, only the stromal component is involved in metastasis. 

Phyllodes tumor is a fibroepithelial tumor arising from the intralobular stroma. It presents as a smooth, rapidly growing, multinodular, painless breast lump that is usually palpable. It most commonly presents in the 6th decade of life and is associated with:

  • Gain in chromosome 1q
  • HOXB13 overexpression

Phyllodes tumors show stromal cellularity next to the epithelium (subepithelial or periepithelial regions). This feature helps to differentiate it from intracanalicular fibroadenoma.

The prognosis of phyllodes tumors depends on their histological grade. Most phyllodes tumors are low grade, with limited stromal cellularity. They recur only occasionally and do not metastasize.

The features of malignant (intermediate and high grade) phyllodes tumors are:

  • Markedly increased stromal cellularity
  • Stromal overgrowth - absence of epithelial elements 
  • Nuclear atypia
  • Increased mitosis (>10/ 10 hpf) 
  • Highly recurrent

Regardless of the grade, lymphatic spread is rare in phyllodes tumors. Hence, axillary lymph node dissection is contraindicated.

questions.text: A 42-year-old HIV-positive patient presented with fever and breathlessness. He has been on antiretroviral therapy for the past 2 weeks and his  CD4 count is 45 cells/cu mm. Imaging shows a lesion in the middle lobe of the lung.  The lung biopsy shows the following findings. What is the likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical details and the characteristic histological image is suggestive of cytomegalovirus (CMV) pneumonia. The image shows a cytomegalic pneumocyte containing characteristic intranuclear basophilic inclusion seperated from the nuclear membrane by a halo (owl’s eye appearance). Within the cytoplasm of infected cells, smaller basophilic inclusions can also be seen

CMV causes an asymptomatic or mononucleosis-like infection in healthy individuals but devastating systemic infections in neonates and in immunocompromised people. In healthy individuals, acute CMV infection induces transient but severe immunosuppression by infecting dendritic cells which causes impairment of antigen processing and T cell stimulation. In immunosuppressed individuals (e.g., transplant recipients, HIV- infected individuals), serious, disseminated CMV infections primarily affect the lungs (pneumonitis) and gastrointestinal tract (gastritis and colitis).

Other options:

Option A: Cryptogenic organizing pneumonia is seen as a response to infection or inflammation to the lungs by virus, bacteria, inhaled toxins and drugs. Histologically COP is characterized by the presence of Masson bodies. These are polypoid plugs of loose organizing connective tissue within alveolar ducts, alveoli and bronchioles along with foci of fibrosis. Patients present with cough and dyspnea and have patchy subpleural or peribronchial areas of consolidation radiographically.

Image showing alveolar spaces filled with balls of fibroblasts (Masson bodies).

 

Option C: Cryptococcal pneumonia is a fungal infection caused by cryptococcus neoformans predominantly in immunosuppressed individuals and rarely in the immunocompetent population. Pulmonary cryptococcosis in AIDS/immunosuppressed patients presents as an interstitial lung disease with lymph node enlargement. The histopathological diagnosis is made by identifying encapsulated yeast forms within sections of the inflammatory lung tissue.

Option D: Giant cell pneumonia is a fatal but rare complication of measles, which is seen in children with immunodeficiency or severe malnutrition. The lymphoid organs, lungs and sputum typically show multinucleate giant cells, called Warthin-Finkeldey cells, which have eosinophilic nuclear and cytoplasmic inclusion bodies.

The image below shows Warthin–Finkeldey giant cell with large grapelike clusters of inclusion bodies.

questions.text:
Match the following microscopic findings to the disease conditions in which they are seen.
Microscopic findings Lung disease
1. Coal-laden macrophages  A. Silicosis
2. Golden-brown fusiform rods  B. Hypersensitivity pneumonitis
3. Non-necrotizing granulomas  C. Anthracosis
4. Nodules of whorled collagen fibers D. Asbestosis
questions.solution:
The correct match is Option 2: 1-C, 2-D, 3-B, 4-A.

Anthracosis/ coal workers' pneumoconiosis is a pulmonary condition seen in coal miners. It is caused due to the phagocytosis of the inhaled carbonaceous pigment by the alveolar or interstitial macrophages and its subsequent accumulation in the connective tissue spaces. With continued exposure, lung tissue undergoes progressive massive fibrosis. The upper lobes and upper zones of the lower lobes of the lungs are commonly involved.

Microscopic features consist of coal-laden macrophages, black pigment, and dense collagenous interstitial fibrosis (in advanced stages), as shown in the image below.

 

Asbestosis occurs due to the inhalation of crystalline hydrated silicates (asbestos). It is characterized by diffuse parenchymal interstitial fibrosis. It usually begins in the lower lobes of the lungs. Other asbestos-related diseases include pleural plaques, recurrent pleural effusions, lung carcinoma, and mesothelioma.

Hallmark microscopic findings are golden brown, fusiform or beaded rods called asbestos bodies, as shown in the image below. These are formed when the asbestos fibers phagocytosed by the macrophages are coated by iron-containing proteinaceous material derived from phagocyte ferritin. Pleural plaques of dense collagen that may be calcified are the most common manifestation of asbestos exposure. They involve the anterior and posterolateral aspects of the parietal pleura and the diaphragmatic domes.

 

Hypersensitivity pneumonitis is an immunologically mediated granulomatous disease that occurs in response to continuous exposure to inhaled organic antigens (mold, hay dust, bird proteins, thermophilic bacteria in air-conditioning units). Pathological changes in response to such exposures are mediated by the CD4+ and CD8+ T-lymphocytes (type IV hypersensitivity reactions) and proinflammatory chemokines.

Microscopic findings include interstitial pneumonitis (lymphocytes, plasma cells, and macrophages) and non-necrotizing granulomas, as shown in the image below. Chronic disease gives rise to obliterative bronchiolitis and honeycombing.

 

Silicosis occurs due to inhalation of crystalline silicon dioxide (silica) as seen in individuals employed in concrete work and sandblasting. Macrophages incorporate inhaled silica particles, thereby activating and releasing inflammatory mediators (IL-1, IL-8) that cause fibroblast recruitment. Subsequently, collagen is deposited in the interstitium. Upper lung zones and hilar lymph nodes are commonly involved.

Microscopy reveals coalescent nodules of whorled collagen fibers surrounded by a peripheral zone of silica-laden macrophages, as shown in the image below. As the disease progresses, these nodules coalesce into scars. Sometimes, thin sheets of calcification can occur in hilar lymph nodes, giving an eggshell appearance.

questions.text: A  59-year old man presented with persistent wheezing, episodes of hemoptysis, and dry cough. Bronchoscopy revealed a mass occluding the left bronchus. Biopsy of the specimen revealed polygonal cells with fine stippled chromatin and eosinophilic cytoplasm arranged in nests. The tumor was positive for CD 56, synaptophysin, and chromogranin. What is the cell of origin of this tumor?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of bronchial carcinoid. Bronchial neuroendocrine tumors (NETs) arise from Kulchitsky cells.

WHO divides neuroendocrine neoplasms into four categories:

  • Typical carcinoid
  • Atypical carcinoid 
  • Large-cell neuroendocrine carcinoma 
  • Small-cell carcinoma 

Carcinoid tumors are low-grade malignant epithelial neoplasms that represent 1% to 5% of all lung tumors. It is not related to smoking. Carcinoids may occur in patients with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1.

On gross examination, these tumors grow as fingerlike or spherical polypoid masses that project into the lumen of the bronchus or as collar button lesions, penetrating the bronchial wall to fan out in the peribronchial tissue.

Histologically, the tumor is composed of organoid, trabecular, palisading, ribbon, or rosette-like arrangements of cells separated by a delicate fibrovascular stroma. On electron microscopy, the cells exhibit the dense-core neurosecretory granules. 

Immunohistochemistry shows positivity for serotonin, neuron-specific enolase, bombesin, calcitonin, or other peptides.

10% of the cases may produce carcinoid syndrome.

Most carcinoids follow a relatively benign course and have good prognosis.

questions.text: A 60 year-old-woman comes with complaints of sudden onset blindness of the right eye, with throbbing headache in the right temporal region associated with jaw claudication. On examination, a thickened tender cord-like structure can be felt in the temple. Temporal artery biopsy shows the following. Which among the following is true about this condition?

choices.text: Lesions are distributed throughout the entire length of the artery
Classic lesions exhibit medial granulomatous inflammation
T cell infiltrates are predominantly CD8+
Fragmentation is seen in external elastic lamina

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and histology image is suggestive of giant cell/temporal arteritis. Classic lesions exhibit medial granulomatous inflammation.

Giant cell/temporal arteritis is a chronic inflammatory disorder of large to small-sized arteries that especially affects the arteries of the head. It is seen in people over 50 years of age.

It can affect the following arteries:

  • Superficial temporal artery: Intense facial pain or headache along the course of the artery
  • Ophthalmic arteries: Sudden and permanent diplopia or blindness
  • Aorta: Giant-cell aortitis
  • Vertebral arteries

A biopsy is needed to confirm the diagnosis. However, a negative biopsy cannot exclude the diagnosis of giant cell arteritis because the lesions are focally distributed(option A), leaving long segments of the artery normal. Hence, the biopsy sample may be taken from the normal part of the artery, leading to a false-negative report. For the same reason, an adequate biopsy requires at least a 1-cm segment.

Biopsy findings of giant cell arteritis include:

  • Classic lesions are primarily medial granulomatous inflammation.
  • These lesions involve the internal elastic lamina, leading to elastic lamina fragmentation.(option D)
  • There is intimal thickening that reduces the luminal diameter.
  • There is an infiltrate with T cells (CD4+ > CD8+)(option C), macrophages, and multinucleated giant cells (75% of specimens).

The image below shows internal elastic lamina fragmentation (black arrow) and giant cells (yellow arrow) in a cerebral artery. 

Corticosteroids and anti-TNF therapies are used for treatment.

questions.text: A 21-year-old previously healthy athlete suffers a sudden cardiac arrest while playing a sport. On autopsy, it was found that there was hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. The gene encoding for which of the following proteins is most commonly mutated in this condition?
questions.solution:
The gene encoding for β-myosin heavy chain (β-MHC) proteins is most commonly mutated in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

HCM is a common autosomal dominant disorder characterized by myocardial hypertrophy, abnormal diastolic filling (with preserved systolic function), and intermittent left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) obstruction. It is the leading cause of unexplained left ventricular hypertrophy.

It is caused by mutations in genes that encode sarcomeric proteins, including myosin-binding protein C (MYBP-C) and β-MHC (MYH7). It can also rarely occur due to mutations in genes coding for cardiac TnI, TnT, and α-tropomyosin.

In HCM, myocardial hypertrophy occurs without ventricular dilation. Furthermore, there is asymmetric septal hypertrophy, where the ventricular septum is disproportionately thickened compared to the left ventricular free wall. The enlarged septum bulges into the ventricular cavity, giving it a banana-like shape. Hypertrophy is most marked in the subaortic region of the septum.

The most important histologic features in HCM are:

  • Massive myocyte hypertrophy
  • Myofiber disarray including that of myocyte bundles, individual myocytes, and contractile elements
  • Fibrotic narrowing of small intramural arteries
  • Interstitial and replacement fibrosis

The images below show normal cardiac myocytes and myofibril disarray in HCM, respectively:

 

Exertional dyspnea due to reduced cardiac output is seen, and a harsh systolic ejection murmur caused due to LVOT obstruction can be heard. Further, atrial fibrillation, stroke due to mural thrombus formation, and ventricular arrhythmias are common complications of HCM. 

β-adrenergic blockers can be used to decrease heart rate and contractility, and implantable cardioverter defibrillators are used for patients with ventricular arrhythmias.

Other options:

Option A: Dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM) occurs due to truncating mutations in the titin gene. The heart in DCM is flabby and hypo-contracting, in contrast with the thick-walled, heavy, and hyper-contracting heart in HCM. Histology reveals hypertrophied myocytes with hyperchromatic distorted nuclei with a ninja star-like appearance, as shown in the image below. Variable degrees of interstitial and endocardial fibrosis is also present.

Option C: Arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy (ARVC) is an autosomal dominant disorder that occurs due to mutations of genes encoding desmosomal junctional proteins. It typically manifests as right-sided heart failure and can cause sudden cardiac death. Histology shows loss of myocytes, fatty infiltration, and focal fibrosis.

Option D: HCM occurs due to mutations in the gene encoding α-tropomyosin. However, this is rare, and HCM occurs most commonly due to mutations in genes encoding myosin-binding protein C (MYBP-C) and β-MHC (MYH7).

questions.text: An autopsy of a 38-year-old male patient who died of cardiac failure showed the following histopathological image of the endocardium. Which of the following best describes the form of vegetation found in this condition?

choices.text: Small, warty vegetations along the line of closure of the valve leaflets
Large, irregular masses on valve cusps and chordae
Small, bland vegetations on the line of closure
Small to medium sized vegetations on either sides of the valve

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette with histopathology showing Anitschkow cells and Aschoff bodies are pathognomic of the rheumatic fever (RF) phase of rheumatic heart disease (RHD). It is associated with small, warty vegetations along the lines of closure of the valve leaflets.

RF is an acute, immunologically mediated, multisystem inflammatory disease classically occurring a few weeks after group A streptococcal pharyngitis. RHD is principally characterized by deforming fibrotic valvular disease, particularly the mitral valve.

Important pathological findings in rheumatic fever are:

  • Inflammation in the three layers of the heart can result in endocarditis, myocarditis, pericarditis, or pancarditis.
  • Inflammation of the endocardium and the left side valves can lead to fibrinoid necrosis. Over these areas of necrosis, small vegetations can be seen along the lines of closure, called verrucae.
  • In the subendocardium, irregular thickenings called MacCallum plaques can be present.
  • Aschoff bodies are collections of lymphocytes (primarily T cells), scattered plasma cells, and plump-activated macrophages (called Anitschkow cells). The Anitschkow cells have abundant cytoplasm and nuclei with chromatin that is centrally condensed into a slender, wavy ribbon. Hence they are also called caterpillar cells.
  • Mitral valve in chronic RHD shows leaflet thickening, commissural fusion and shortening, and thickening and fusion of the tendinous cords.This leads to narrowing of the mitral orifice, giving it a fish mouth appearance.

questions.solution:
In the given image, images marked 1 is normal liver, 2 is alcoholic steatosis, 3 is micronodular cirrhosis and 4 is alcoholic hepatitis.

Histopathological findings in the following conditions are:

  • Alcoholic steatosis:
    • A mix of small and large fat droplets
    • Ethanol inhibits fatty acid metabolism, leading to lipolysis and increased triglyceride. These triglycerides accumulate and cause steatosis. Liver enzymes are normal at this stage.
  • Micronodular cirrhosis:
    • The average nodule size is 3 mm in this close-up view, which is typical of the micronodular cirrhosis of alcoholic liver disease

questions.text: A 52-year-old male patient presented with abdominal pain and melena. On endoscopy, a bleeding gastric mass with irregular borders was identified along the greater curvature of the stomach. Microscopy is as shown in the image below. Which of the following is a specific marker for the tumor?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the histological picture showing spindle-shaped tumor cells are suggestive of gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST), for which CD 117 is the specific marker. 

GIST is the most common mesenchymal tumor of the abdomen, with the most common site being the stomach. The tumor arises from the interstitial cells of Cajal or pacemaker cells of the gastrointestinal muscularis propria.

Most GISTs occur due to gain-of-function mutations in receptor tyrosine kinase KIT (~75%) or PDGRF-ɑ (~8%). 

The tumor peaks at 60 years of age. It is often associated with the Carney triad, a nonhereditary condition characterized by GIST, paraganglioma, and pulmonary chondroma. GIST also has a higher incidence in individuals with neurofibromatosis I.

Patients typically present with anemia (due to blood loss caused by mucosal ulceration) and symptoms of mass effect. However, GISTs may also be discovered incidentally during imaging or surgery.

Microscopically, GIST can be of two patterns:

  1. Spindle cell type: The tumor is composed of thin elongated cells.
  2. Epitheloid type: The tumor is composed of plump epithelial-like cells.

Mixed patterns may also be seen.

The most useful immunohistochemical marker is KIT (CD117) detectable in Cajal cells.

The prognosis depends on tumor size, mitotic index, and location (GISTs arising in the stomach are less aggressive than those arising in the small intestine). Complete surgical resection is the mainstay treatment. For unresectable, recurrent, or metastatic GISTs, imatinib, a tyrosine kinase inhibitor, can be used.

questions.text: A middle-aged man presents to the outpatient department with fever, epigastric discomfort, progressive weight loss, arthralgia, and foul-smelling diarrhea for the past 6 months. There is no relation between the abdominal pain and his bowel movements. He was started on a restrictive diet, which showed no improvement. His biopsy is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The symptoms of this patient along with the given slide showing macrophages filled with PAS-positive inclusions point to a diagnosis of Whipple's disease.

The morphologic hallmark of Whipple disease is a dense accumulation of distended, foamy macrophages in the small intestinal lamina propria. Macrophages contain periodic acid–Schiff (PAS)-positive, diastase-resistant granules that represent lysosomes stuffed with partially digested bacteria.

Whipple's disease is a chronic multisystem disorder caused by a gram-positive bacteria Tropheryma whipplei. It is characterized by a triad of diarrhea, weight loss, and arthralgia. Malabsorptive diarrhea of Whipple's disease is due to bacteria-laden macrophages that accumulate within the small intestinal lamina propria and mesenteric lymph nodes causing lymphatic obstruction. Extraintestinal symptoms may precede malabsorption.

Histopathological findings: 

  • A dense accumulation of distended, foamy macrophages is seen in the small intestinal lamina propria; these macrophages contain PAS-positive, diastase-resistant granules, which indicate partially digested bacteria with lysosomes—a hallmark of Whipple's disease.
  • With disease progression, there is villous atrophy, crypt hyperplasia, and apoptosis of surface epithelial cells in the intestine, which can cause diarrhoea due to decreased absorption and increased efflux of water and solutes.
  • Non-caseating granulomas may also be seen.
  • Bacteria-laden macrophages can accumulate within mesenteric lymph nodes, synovial membranes, cardiac valves, brain, or other sites.

The diagnosis of Whipple's disease is primarily established by endoscopic biopsy and histological evaluation. The remainder of the cases are diagnosed by PCR which can be done on duodenal biopsies or fluids (such as CSF and synovial fluid) or tissues.

Other options:

Option A: Irritable bowel syndrome presents with recurrent abdominal pain that may be related to defecation, associated with a change in frequency, or associated with a change in appearance. Despite having these symptoms, the endoscopy and microscopic examination are normal in patients with irritable bowel syndrome.

Option C: Cystic fibrosis is a congenital disorder due to a mutation in the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) gene located on chromosome 7. It leads to abnormal transport of chloride and bicarbonate ions in the lungs, gastrointestinal tract, pancreas, and reproductive tract. 

Option D: Celiac disease is an autoimmune gluten-induced enteropathy where there is an excessive inflammatory response to gluten and its breakdown product, gliadin. This leads to inflammatory infiltration of the lamina propria which subsequently impairs various nutrient absorption.

questions.text: A 3-month-old baby boy had recurrent episodes of bacterial infection. There is also a history of bloody diarrhoea and eczema during the first month of life. Peripheral smear showed abnormally small-sized platelets. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Wiskott–Aldrich syndrome.

Wiskott–Aldrich syndrome is an X-linked recessive disease characterized by thrombocytopenia and small-sized platelets. Patients often present in infancy with bruising, bloody diarrhea, eczema, and susceptibility to recurrent infections. It occurs due to mutations in the gene located at Xp11.23 that encodes Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome protein (WASP).

Along with microthrombocytopenia, peripheral smear shows loss of T lymphocytes. Patients are also unable to produce antibodies to antigens, thereby making them immunocompromised. As a result, there is also an increased risk of autoimmune disorders and cancers like B-cell lymphomas.

Splenectomy improves platelet counts in these patients since increased platelet destruction in the spleen is prevented. However, the only definitive treatment is hematopoietic stem cell transplantation.

Other options:

Option A: Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) is a thrombohemorrhagic disorder characterized by the formation of microthrombi in the microcirculation of the body. Laboratory investigations show decreased platelets and coagulation factors decreased fibrin, increased fibrin degradation products, and prolonged prothrombin time.

Option B: Idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) is a condition characterized by low platelet count due to autoantibody-mediated destruction. Patients present with easy bruising, nosebleeds, gingival bleeding, and bleeding into the skin and soft tissues. Laboratory findings typically show isolated thrombocytopenia.

Option C: Bernard-Soulier syndrome is an autosomal recessive condition occurring due to defective adhesion of platelets to the subendothelial extracellular matrix. It is due to a deficiency of the glycoprotein complex Ib–IX on the platelet membrane. Patients often present with bleeding tendencies.

    • Drug-induced: alcohol, thiazides, cytotoxic drugs
    • Infections: measles, human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)
  2. Nutritional deficiencies - megaloblastic leukemia
  3. Bone marrow failure - aplastic anemia
  4. Bone marrow replacement - leukemia, disseminated cancer, granulomatous disease
  5. Ineffective hematopoiesis - myelodysplastic syndromes 

II. Decreased Platelet Survival

  1. Immunologic destruction
    • Primary autoimmune - chronic immune thrombocytopenic purpura, acute immune thrombocytopenic purpura
    • Secondary autoimmune - systemic lupus erythematosus, B-cell lymphoid neoplasms
    • Alloimmune: posttransfusion and neonatal
    • Drug-associated: quinidine, heparin, sulfa compounds
    • Infections: HIV, infectious mononucleosis (transient, mild), dengue fever
  2. Nonimmunologic destruction

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presented with a history of lymph node enlargement in his neck and axillae for the past 3 weeks. Investigations revealed mild anemia with leukocytosis of 40,000/mm3. The peripheral blood smear is shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL). CLL is a tumor of mature B cells and the most common leukemia in adults.

Patients with CLL present with nonspecific symptoms like easy fatigability, weight loss, and anorexia. Generalized lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly are present in about 50-60% of cases. There is also increased susceptibility to infections due to disruption of immune processes.

The peripheral smear, as shown in the image below, typically shows small round lymphocytes with condensed chromatin and scant cytoplasm (indicated by arrows). Some of these cells get disrupted while preparing the smear; these cells are called smudge cells (indicated by arrowheads).

Other options:

Option A: Acute lymphoblastic lymphoma (ALL) is a tumor of immature B or T cells and the most common leukemia in children. The peripheral blood smear shows lymphoblasts with condensed nuclear chromatin, small nucleoli, and scant agranular cytoplasm.

Option C: Multiple myeloma is a neoplasm of plasma cells. It is also typically associated with punched-out bony lesions, hypercalcemia, and renal. Bone marrow aspirate shows plasma cells with multiple nuclei and prominent nucleoli. Serum protein electrophoresis shows a spike of M protein (monoclonal immunoglobulin).

Option D: Waldenström macroglobulinemia is a hyperviscosity syndrome caused due to excess amounts of monoclonal IgM secreted by plasma cells. It is a type of lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma, with bone marrow aspirate showing small lymphocytes with variable degrees of plasma differentiation.

questions.text: What is the underlying pathology in patients with Conn's syndrome?
questions.solution:
The underlying pathology in patients with Conn's syndrome is adrenal adenoma.

Hyperaldosteronism may be primary or secondary. 

Primary hyperaldosteronism is due to autonomous overproduction of aldosterone with resultant suppression of RAAS. It can occur due to adrenal hyperplasia, adenoma, or carcinoma. It presents with the following features:

  • Hypertension (most common)
  • Hypokalemia
  • Metabolic alkalosis
  • Polyuria (due to ANP)
  • Polydipsia (due to polyuria)
  • Muscle weakness

It is confirmed by elevated ratios of plasma aldosterone concentration to plasma renin activity (PAC / PRA).

When primary hyperaldosteronism is due to an aldosterone-secreting adenoma, it is called Conn syndrome. Patients are usually treated with spironolactone followed by surgical removal of adenoma. In patients treated with spironolactone, the adenomas contain eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions called spironolactone bodies.

In secondary hyperaldosteronism, aldosterone release occurs in response to the activation of the renin-angiotensin system (RAAS).

questions.text: A patient with a history of peptic ulcer underwent upper GI endoscopic biopsy of the stomach. The biopsy is stained with a special stain and shown in the image. What is the special stain used?
questions.solution:
The given slide shows the GI mucosa, which has been stained with Warthin-Starry silver stain, demonstrating the bacilli (Helicobacter pylori) causing type B gastritis.

On antral biopsy, H. pylori organisms are seen abundantly within the surface mucus layer, but they are difficult to visualize with routine hematoxylin (H&E) stains. Organisms are most easily demonstrated with special stains like Warthin starry silver stain or Giemsa stain.

  • It commonly affects the antrum.
  • Intestinal metaplasia is associated with chronic pan-gastritis with atrophy.
  • Intestinal metaplasia with dysplasia has malignant potential.

H. pylori infection is also a risk factor for the following:

  • Peptic ulcer disease (duodenal > gastric)
  • Gastric adenocarcinoma
  • Gastric lymphoma

questions.text: A 25-year-old female patient came to the hospital with rashes, arthralgia, myalgia, and photosensitivity for a week. She was diagnosed with tuberculosis and has been on anti-tubercular treatment for the past 3 months. She has no past history of similar episodes. Serum auto-antibody associated with her condition is?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis for the patient's current symptoms is drug-induced lupus erythematosus (DILE).  Anti-histone antibody, an antibody against histone associated with DNA in chromatin, is seen particularly in cases of drug- induced lupus than SLE.

Isoniazid is one of the most common causes of DILE. The rash is spread over both cheeks, forming the typical malar rash. The patient also has other systemic symptoms including arthralgia and myalgia. The patient will be positive for anti-histone antibodies.

Drug-induced lupus usually occurs after 2-3 months of exposure to the offending drug and will spontaneously resolve on stopping the drug.

SLE is an autoimmune disease involving multiple organs, characterized by a vast array of autoantibodies, particularly antinuclear antibodies (ANAs), in which injury is caused mainly by the deposition of immune complexes and binding of antibodies to various cells and tissues.

An SLE like syndrome may develop in patients receiving variety of drugs, including 

  • Hydralazine
  • Procainamide
  • Isoniazid
  • Chlorpromazine
  • D- Penicillamine
  • Anti- TNF Therapy

Many of these drugs are associated with the development of ANAs, but most patients do not have symptoms of SLE. Anti-histone antibodies are present in 75% of cases of DIL.

The mainstay of treatment is recognition and discontinuation of the offending drug. Development of positive ANA alone after receiving a drug shall not be a reason for discontinuation of the drug, although these patients shall be closely monitored for the development of DIL. Symptoms of DIL usually resolve within a few weeks of discontinuation of the medication, although rarely, they may last several months. NSAIDs or low dose corticosteroids may be considered for milder manifestations, with high dose corticosteroids reserved for more serious manifestations such as symptomatic pericardial effusion. 

Other options:

Option A: Anti-mitochondrial antibodies are specific for primary biliary cirrhosis.

Option B: Rheumatoid factor is an IgM antibody directed against the Fc fragment of self IgG found in patients with rheumatoid arthritis. It is also found in other collagen tissue disorders.

Option C: Anti-centromere antibodies are present in the majority of patients with the calcinosis, Raynaud phenomenon, esophageal dysmotility, sclerodactyly, and telangiectasia (CREST) syndrome.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman who is a known case of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (EDS) presents with severe abdominal pain, hypotension, and decreased level of consciousness. On further examination, colonic artery rupture was discovered. This occurs due to the defects in which type of collagen in EDS?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes a typical case of vascular type of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (EDS) that occurs due to defects in type III collagen.

EDS is a connective tissue disorder occuring due to genetic defects involved in collagen synthesis and action. It is characterized by hyperextensibility of skin, hypermobile joints, easy bruising, and poor wound healing.

The vascular variant of EDS has an autosomal dominant mode of inheritance. It was previously known as type IV EDS. It results from defects in type III collagen and occurs due to a mutation in the COL3A1 gene. Unlike other types of EDS, hyperextensibility of skin is absent in the vascular type of EDS. The skin is thin and translucent with visible veins. Other features of vascular EDS include arterial rupture, uterine rupture, bruising, and small joint hyperextensibility.

The collagen defects in other variants of EDS are:

  • Arthrochalasia and dermatosparaxis EDS: Defective conversion of type I procollagen to collagen
  • Classical EDS: Mutation in the gene encoding type V collagen

Note: The classification of EDS in the pearl is based on clinical subtypes of EDS and not based on the type of collagen involved in the disease. The numbers in brackets indicate the Roman numbers used by the previous classification (not the type of collagen involved).

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient presents with a bulky scrotal swelling. On resection, the testicular mass is found to be homogenous, grey-white, and does not show hemorrhage or necrosis. The histopathological image is shown below. Which of the following is true for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and histological image is suggestive of seminoma of the testes, and human chorionic gonadotropin (HCG) levels may be elevated.

"Classic" or "typical" seminomas are the most common type of germ cell tumor. They are bulky, homogenous, pale, and well-circumscribed masses that do not show any hemorrhage or necrosis, as shown in the image below. 

Microscopically, sheets of uniform tumor cells divided into poorly demarcated lobules by fibrous septa are seen. Each cell is large, round, and has a distinct cell membrane, abundant clear cytoplasm, and a large central nucleus with a few nucleoli.

In about 15% of cases, serum HCG levels are raised as these seminomas contain syncytiotrophoblasts. Lactate dehdrogenase (LDH) levels are also measured to assess tumor burden.

Therapy depends on the stage of the tumor. Seminoma has the best prognosis. Most cases of seminoma stages I and II can be cured by orchiectomy with or without chemotherapy or radiotherapy.

Other options:

Option B: ɑ-fetoprotein (AFP) levels are elevated in yolk sac tumors.

Options C and D: Seminoma cells stain positive for KIT, OCT3/4, and podoplanin and negative for cytokeratin by immunohistochemistry.

questions.text:
A tall man presents with absent pubic and axillary hair, infantile genitalia, and high LH and FSH levels with XXY karyotype. What is the most probable diagnosis?

LH- Luteinizing hormone, FSH- Follicle-stimulating hormone
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is indicative of Klinefelter's syndrome (KS).

KS refers to male hypogonadism occurring when there are 2 or more X chromosomes and 1 or more Y chromosomes. The classic form of KS is associated with a 47 XXY karyotype, which occurs after meiotic nondisjunction of the sex chromosomes during gametogenesis.

KS is characterized by:

  • Small atrophied testes with a small penis
  • Hypogonadism
  • Male infertility
  • Tall stature or increased leg length
  • Gynecomastia
  • Loss of secondary sexual characteristics like a deep voice and male facial and pubic hair distribution

Patients are at risk for type 2 diabetes and metabolic syndrome (due to increased insulin resistance), congenital cardiac anomalies like mitral valve prolapse, atrial and ventricular septal defects, osteoporosis (due to sex hormone imbalances), breast cancer, and autoimmune diseases like SLE.

Plasma concentrations of FSH, LH, and estradiol are increased and plasma testosterone are decreased.

Other options:

Option A. Vanishing testis syndrome is testicular atrophy occurring due to persistent stimulation by high FSH levels. In severe cases, there is complete regression of the testis; hence, the name, vanishing testis. A normal karyotype (46 XY) is seen in these individuals.

Option C. Fragile X syndrome is the most common genetic cause of intellectual disability in males, occuring due to a trinucleotide expansion mutation in the familial mental retardation 1 gene. The most characteristic physical feature is macro-orchidism, that is, large testicles. They also have a long face with a large mandible and large everted ears.

Option D. Congenital adrenal hyperplasia is a group of autosomal recessive disorders, most commonly occurring due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency. This causes a block in steroid production, resulting in increased ACTH secretion and excess androgens. Thus, these patients present with bilateral adrenal hyperplasia, virilism (masculinization in females and precocious puberty in males), and salt wasting syndrome.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man came with complaints of bilateral pedal edema and decreased urine output for the past one month. He has a past history of diabetes mellitus and has not been under regular treatment. The following histopathological image was obtained after a biopsy. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given histopathological image shows PAS-positive nodules suggestive of nodular glomerulosclerosis which is seen in diabetic nephropathy.

Nodular glomerulosclerosis, also known as Kimmelstiel-Wilson lesion is a glomerular lesion characterized by spherical-ovoid deposits of a laminated matrix in the periphery of the glomerulus surrounded by patent or dilated capillary loops. These nodules are PAS-positive and usually contain trapped mesangial cells. The nodules often show features of mesangiolysis, defined as disruption of anchoring interactions between the capillaries and the mesangial stalks, which leads to the formation of capillary aneurysms.

Nodular glomerulosclerosis is encountered in approximately 15% to 30% of individuals with long-term diabetes and is a major contributor to renal dysfunction.

The lesions encountered in diabetic nephropathy are:

  • Glomerular lesions: Capillary basement membrane thickening, diffuse mesangial sclerosis, and nodular glomerulosclerosis.
  • Renal vascular lesions, principally arteriolosclerosis
  • Pyelonephritis, including necrotizing papillitis.

Other options:

Option B: Crescentic glomerulonephritis is also known as rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN). Histopathology will show compressed glomerular tufts by a crescent-shaped mass of epithelial cells and leukocytes.

Option C:  glomerulonephritis (MPGN) is a pattern of immune-mediated injury. MPGN is characterized histologically by changes in the glomerular basement membrane, multiplication of glomerular cells, and the presence of deposits in the mesangial area and glomerular capillaries. The basement membrane shows a 'double-contour' or 'tram-track' appearance on silver or PAS stains. 

Option D: Segmental glomerulosclerosis is characterized by presence of focal and segmental sclerotic lesions of glomeruli which show obliteration of capillary lumens and deposition of plasma proteins along the capillary wall (hyalinosis). On electron microscopy, there is diffuse effacement of foot processes.

questions.text: A child presented with cola-colored urine, hypertension, and puffiness of eyes. Creatinine was 2.5 mg/dl. Treatment was started and despite treatment, the patient did not improve for the next 3 weeks. The creatinine value increased to 4.5mg/dl. Which among the following electron microscopic findings will be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis based on the above clinical scenario is post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis. Subepithelial deposits will be seen on electron microscopy.

Poststreptococcal GN is uncommon before the age of 3 years and most prevalent in kids between the ages of 5 and 12. The patient typically develops an acute nephritic syndrome following:

  • 1 to 2 weeks after streptococcal pharyngitis or
  • 3 to 6 weeks after streptococcal pyoderma

From asymptomatic microscopic hematuria with normal renal function to gross hematuria with acute renal failure, the severity of kidney involvement varies. Patients may experience different levels of edema, hypertension, and oliguria depending on the extent of the renal involvement.

Laboratory findings: More than 90% of patients see a considerable reduction in serum C3 levels during the acute phase, which lasts 6 to 8 weeks before returning to normal. 
In order to confirm the diagnosis, evidence of preceding streptococcal infection is required. The antistreptolysin O titer frequently rises following pharyngeal infections. The anti-deoxyribonuclease B level is the most effective single antibody titer to demonstrate cutaneous streptococcal infection.

Microscopic Findings in PSGN:
  • Light microscopy: Enlarged, hypercellular glomeruli with diffuse mesangial and endothelial proliferation and leukocyte infiltration.
  • Immunofluorescence: Granular deposits of IgG and complement C3 along the glomerular basement membrane(GBM)and in the mesangium. 
  • Electron microscopy: Primarily subepithelial humps are seen. Subendothelial deposits in early disease stages can be seen.

questions.text: A patient underwent kidney transplantation due to severe diabetic nephropathy. A few months later, he presented with fever, malaise, and flank pain. During evaluation, oliguria and an acute rise in creatinine levels were observed. A biopsy of the kidney showed endotheliitis. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and the biopsy findings of endotheliitis suggest a diagnosis of acute cell-mediated graft rejection.

In acute cell-mediated graft rejection, CD8+ CTLs directly destroy graft cells or CD4+ cells secrete cytokines that damage the graft.

On histopathology, it produces two different patterns of injury:

  • Tubulointerstitial pattern (type I): extensive interstitial and tubular inflammation associated with focal tubular injury
  • Vascular pattern - Inflammation (type II) and necrosis (type III), endotheliitis (swollen endothelial cells with lymphocytes between endothelium and vessel wall)

Immunosuppressive therapy aims to prevent and reduce acute rejection by blocking the activation of alloreactive T cells. In the absence of humoral rejection, patients respond well to immunosuppressive therapy.
